alignments.name: NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework
alignments.description: The NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework (NICE Framework), NIST Special Publication 800-181, is a national-focused resource that categorizes and describes cybersecurity work. The NICE Framework establishes a taxonomy and common lexicon that describes cybersecurity work and workers irrespective of where or for whom the work is performed.

NBPTS Career and Technical Education Standard IV: Learning Environments and Instructional Practices. Accomplished teachers design contextualized learning environments that foster critical thinking, creativity, leadership, teamwork, and communication skills while preparing students for postsecondary education and careers.

NBPTS Career and Technical Education Standard VI Postsecondary Readiness: Accomplished teachers facilitate career exploration and promote the acquisition of knowledge and skills so students can make informed career decisions that match their interests and aptitudes with the needs, expectations, and requirements of industry.

NBPTS Career and Technical Education Standard VII Program Design and Management: Accomplished teachers design and promote quality programs aligned with industry demands. They manage materials and resources to enrich their programs and sustain meaningful educational experiences for their students.

NBPTS Career and Technical Education Standard VIII Partnerships and Collaborations: Accomplished teachers collaborate with family, education, industry, and community partners to create challenging real world opportunities and support networks that help students plan, develop, and achieve their career goals.

NBPTS Career and Technical Education Standard Specialty Area: Information Systems and Technology. Accomplished CTE teachers in information systems and technology have a comprehensive understanding of the design, development, and management of computer software, hardware, and networks.

NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework - K0252 - Knowledge of training and education principles and methods for curriculum design, teaching and instruction for individuals and groups, and the measurement of training and education effects.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework - K0628 - Knowledge of cyber competitions as a way of developing skills by providing hands-on experience in simulated, real-world situations.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework - A0057 - Ability to tailor curriculum that speaks to the topic at the appropriate level for the target audience.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework - A0114 - Ability to develop or procure curriculum that speaks to the topic at the appropriate level for the target.

39de7c31-6b70-4de2-8847-06fdf34a034d.description: Earners of this badge were part of a team awarded 1st place in the California Mayors Cyber Cup 2019 for their region. California Cyberhub recognizes that the Earners of the award demonstrated their knowledge of the core concepts of cybersecurity in the competition offered by Sentek Global’s Hai:ku Range. The team was an elite task-force that helped to find, suppress, and kill the commands planted on eleven machines from points across the globe to prevent an attack on America’s power grid.

badge_template_activities.title: Flag 43 - Your team is tasked to investigate and find any potential evidence relating to the "home-away-from-home signaling units".

Flag 44 - The intercepted message stated information about a possible implant that could affect specific processes of a plant, are any systems showing signs of this type of activity based on the intel already provided.

Flag 45 - Technicians from the SERC Regional Station have reported more frequent events with power GENERATION issues, causing temporary blackouts and destruction of local power equipment. Identify what is causing this issue.

Flag 46 - One of the power stations appears to be distributing electricity above the max allowable threshold to maintain the load balancing capabilities for the region, you have been tasked to validate the power production and distribution at the plant.

Flag 48 - In order for the adversary to more easily coordinate their actions, it appears that they are monitoring our own systems. How is the adversary getting data from the region, in order to trigger follow-on events? It is your task to determine how data is leaking.
Flag 49 - What protocol is used for terminal services within the nerc.energy.grid domain?
Flag 50 - What is the name of the system monitoring the electric grid?
Flag 51 - What does ICS stand for?
Flag 52 - What is the system command to restart the following service?
Flag 53 - You were notified that a technician had questions about how to monitor the electric grid. What is the URL for Nations Eye?
Flag 54 - How do you view user account information, and can you find the associated flag?
Flag 55 - How do you view processes on a system, and can you find the associated flag?
Flag 56 - Your team needs to identify whether any of the power plants have issues concerning authentication, are there any accounts that pose an issue?

Flag 57 - It has been reported that there is a rogue system being detected. You will not have access to this system; however, it appears to have placed hidden SECRETS that are hiding within the region.
Flag 58 - The controller at the SERC power station appears to be malfunctioning causing power spikes, although local technicians cannot find any issues with the equipment.
Flag 59 - The controller at the SERC power station appears to be malfunctioning causing power spikes, although local technicians cannot find any issues with the equipment.
Flag 60 - U.S. Cyber Command was able to identify further message traffic related to an imminent attack on the electric grid. Find and mitigate the threat without breaking the station.
Flag 61 - What Power Plant does this region collect data for, but is not able to manage via Terminal Access?
Flag 63 - What port is being used to transfer all the power plant data to the Nations Eye monitoring system?
Flag 64 - What is the name of the utility that the Power Plant Console is made from?
Flag 65 - When reviewing the log data from the Power Plants, what message type shows ONLINE or OFFLINE?

Flag 66 - Your team has mitigated several issues within the Nation's Power Grid. Ensure you review the knowledge portal and identify how to restore the baseline settings to power station to prevent cascading events.

Flag 67 - Your team has been tasked with ensuring appropriate ports and protocols are being utilized. A manager in one of the regions was identified last quarter's report of violations for federal networking procedures.
Flag 68 - Your team is tasked with verifying access across the electric grid systems, You need to ensure that there are no unauthorized or rogue accounts being utilized.

Flag 69 - The automated backup log transfer for their power plant data was unsuccessful. This is needed in order to perform big data analysis from last quarters data. Identify where the backup logs are on the manager, and analyze them to determine why the transfer never occurred.

Flag 70 - You have been notified that Cyber Command uncovered a portion of a malicious script that they believe is part of the final kill commands. They identified that the destination was somewhere within the region.
Flag 71 - What distributed network protocol is currently being utilized within electrical companies?
Flag 72 - What does HMI stand for?
Flag 73 - Telnet was replaced by what secure program in order to provide more secure terminal services?
Flag 74 - When it is time for Challenge 1 to be available a flag will be provided in a notification.  Enter the FLAG from notification to unlock Challenge 1.
Flag 75 - When it is time for Challenge 2 to be available a flag will be provided in a notification.  Enter the FLAG from the notification to unlock Challenge 2.
Flag 76 - When it is time for Challenge 3 to be available a flag will be provided in a notification.  Enter the FLAG from the notification to unlock Challenge 3.
Flag 77 - A recently terminated domain administrator was found to have left several backdoors can you see if you can find one?
Flag 78 - Sally Clemson a local department manager has reported she seems to have more rights than she should.
Flag 79 - U.S. Cyber Command has received notice of traffic being sent to one of the power plants in the MRO Region.

5f33147a-034c-4f43-92c3-132e7705fd72.description: Earners of this badge attended the Advanced CyberPatriot Camp June 2020 and participated in 20+ hours of immersive training and online curriculum. Earners used virtual imaging software and industry standard practicum labs to self-assess their abilities and knowledge while acquiring new skills.
5f33147a-034c-4f43-92c3-132e7705fd72.name: Advanced CyberPatriot Camp

badge_template_activities.title: Register for the camp using Eventbrite.
Complete camp survey.
Complete all CyberPatriot activity worksheets.
Complete course with a minimum of 4 out of 12 Practice Labs exercises, from CompTIA IT Fundamentals+, A+, Network+ or Security+ modules.
Participate in daily discussion groups, responding to key prompts in regard to daily instructional learning modules and activities.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0001 -  Knowledge of computer networking concepts and protocols, and network security methodologies.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0002 - Knowledge of risk management processes (e.g., methods for assessing and mitigating risk).
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0003 - Knowledge of laws, regulations, policies, and ethics as they relate to cybersecurity and privacy.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0004 - Knowledge of cybersecurity and privacy principles.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0005 - Knowledge of cyber threats and vulnerabilities.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0006 - Knowledge of specific operational impacts of cybersecurity lapses.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0013 - Knowledge of cyber defense and vulnerability assessment tools and their capabilities.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0046 - Knowledge of intrusion detection methodologies and techniques for detecting host and network-based intrusions.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0049 - Knowledge of information technology (IT) security principles and methods (e.g., firewalls, demilitarized zones, encryption).
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0060 - Knowledge of operating systems.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0075 - Knowledge of security system design tools, methods, and techniques.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0129 - Knowledge of command-line tools (e.g., mkdir, mv, ls, passwd, grep).
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0157 - Knowledge of cyber defense and information security policies, procedures, and regulations.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0167 - Knowledge of system administration, network, and operating system hardening techniques.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0290 - Knowledge of systems security testing and evaluation methods.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0318 - Knowledge of operating system command-line tools.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0332 - Knowledge of network protocols such as TCP/IP, Dynamic Host Configuration, Domain Name System (DNS), and directory services.

4adbcdaf-8cd9-4c40-b00b-109483997067.description: The earner of this badge was a team member that won second place in the Middle School division at the Inland Empire Desert Regional 2022 California Mayors Cyber Cup on March 12, 2022. This cybersecurity competition featured the Cyber Skyline platform and was a 3-hour competition. Cyber-Guild recognizes that the Earners of the award demonstrated their knowledge of the core concepts of cybersecurity in the competition offered by Cyber Skyline.
4adbcdaf-8cd9-4c40-b00b-109483997067.name: 2022 California Mayors Cyber Cup Second Place - Inland Empire Desert Region Middle School Division

alignments.name: NIST 800-181 Workforce Framework for Cybersecurity (NICE Framework)
alignments.description: NIST 800-181 revision 1, the Workforce Framework for Cybersecurity (NICE Framework) provides a set of building blocks for describing the tasks, knowledge, abilities and skills that are needed to perform cybersecurity work.

badge_template_activities.title: Registration in the Inland Empire Desert Regional 2022 California Mayors Cyber Cup via the Cyber Skyline game platform and participation in the full 3-hour competition.
Acquire skills through the Cyber Skyline game platform practice gymnasium and competition.
Achieve the second highest score in division.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0001: Knowledge of computer networking concepts and protocols, and network security methodologies.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0005: Knowledge of cyber threats and vulnerabilities.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0009: Knowledge of application vulnerabilities.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0013: Knowledge of cyber defense and vulnerability assessment tools and their capabilities.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0018: Knowledge of encryption algorithms.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0019: Knowledge of cryptography and cryptographic key management concepts.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0024: Knowledge of database systems.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0040: Knowledge of vulnerability information dissemination sources (e.g., alerts, advisories, errata, and bulletins).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0042: Knowledge of incident response and handling methodologies.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0052: Knowledge of mathematics (e.g. logarithms, trigonometry, linear algebra, calculus, statistics, and operational analysis).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0056: Knowledge of network access, identity, and access management (e.g., public key infrastructure, Oauth, OpenID, SAML, SPML).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0058: Knowledge of network traffic analysis methods.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0119: Knowledge of hacking methodologies.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0145: Knowledge of security event correlation tools.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0224: Knowledge of system administration concepts for operating systems such as but not limited to Unix/Linux, IOS, Android, and Windows operating systems.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0301: Knowledge of packet-level analysis using appropriate tools (e.g., Wireshark, tcpdump).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0308: Knowledge of cryptology.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0342: Knowledge of penetration testing principles, tools, and techniques.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0427: Knowledge of encryption algorithms and cyber capabilities/tools (e.g., SSL, PGP).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0428: Knowledge of encryption algorithms and tools for wireless local area networks (WLANs).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0480: Knowledge of malware.

NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0565: Knowledge of the common networking and routing protocols (e.g. TCP/IP), services (e.g., web, mail, DNS), and how they interact to provide network communications.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0057: Skill in using protocol analyzers.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0087: Skill in deep analysis of captured malicious code (e.g., malware forensics).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0089: Skill in one-way hash functions (e.g., Secure Hash Algorithm [SHA], Message Digest Algorithm [MD5]).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0092: Skill in identifying obfuscation techniques.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0156: Skill in performing packet-level analysis.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0221: Skill in extracting information from packet captures.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0242: Skill in interpreting vulnerability scanner results to identify vulnerabilities.

NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0270: Skill in reverse engineering (e.g., hex editing, binary packaging utilities, debugging, and strings analysis) to identify function and ownership of remote tools.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0298: Skill in verifying the integrity of all files. (e.g., checksums, Exclusive OR, secure hashes, check constraints, etc.).

alignments.name: NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework
alignments.description: The National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Cybersecurity Workforce Framework (NICE Framework), published by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in NIST Special Publication 800-181, is a nationally focused resource that establishes a taxonomy and common lexicon to describe cybersecurity work and workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Participate in Wicked 6 Cyber Games Qualification Round, Round 1 of the Wicked6 Tournament and the Wicked6 Final Round.
Acquire skills through Project Ares, a gamified, AI-powered cybersecurity platform by Circadence™.

Completed Qualification Round Mission 2M (Individual)-Operation Bear Treat (Offensive: Stop Terrorist Financing), with the following mission objectives: #1- Find the target web server, #2- Exploit a vulnerability, #3- Gain administrative access, #4- Gather credentials, #5- Identify and access internal system, #6- Retrieve bank account data .

Completed Qualification Round Mission 5E (Team)-Operation Wounded Bear (Defensive: Protect Financial Institution), with the following mission objectives: #1- Use IDS/IPS to alert/ block initial malware infection vectors, #2- Alert/ prevent download of malicious executables, #3- Create alert for infections, #4- Remove malware from initially infected machine, #5- Find and remove other instances of malware, #6- Prevent further infections.

Completed Round 1 Mission 10E (Team)-Operation Crimson Wolf (Defensive: Ransomware), with the following mission objectives: #1- Verify networking monitoring tools are functioning, #2- Examine current email policies for risk, #3- Examine domain group/user policies for risk, #4- Verify Ransomware download.

Completed Final Round Mission 9E (Team)-Operation Mongoose (Manipulate Industrial Control System), with the following mission objectives: #1- Connect to the payload beaconing inside the payload network, #2- Find and open the documentation related to the PLC, #3- Identify the Modbus systems on the network, #4- Make a connection to the open Modbus port on the PLC system on the inside of the network, #5- Change the state of the valve parameter.

880317d1-18fb-43d8-907c-4011948d2b03.description: Earners of this badge have placed first place in the Wicked6 Cyber Games, a unique cybersecurity exhibition & fundraiser for Women's Society of Cyberjutsu at HyperX Esports Arena Las Vegas at the Luxor Hotel & Casino on August 8, 2019. The Wicked6 Cyber Games are designed to simulate industry-specific cyber-attack scenarios. Competitors exhibit critical cyber defense skills that directly map to abilities that corporate recruiters seek to fill the growing number of IT security jobs.
880317d1-18fb-43d8-907c-4011948d2b03.name: Wicked6 Cyber Games Champion

alignments.name: NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework
alignments.description: The National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Cybersecurity Workforce Framework (NICE Framework), published by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) in NIST Special Publication 800-181, is a nationally focused resource that establishes a taxonomy and common lexicon to describe cybersecurity work and workers.

badge_template_activities.title: Participate in Wicked 6 Cyber Games Qualification Round, Round 1 of the Wicked6 Tournament and the Wicked6 Final Round.
Acquire skills through Project Ares, a gamified, AI-powered cybersecurity platform by Circadence™.

Completed Qualification Round Mission 2M (Individual)-Operation Bear Treat (Offensive: Stop Terrorist Financing), with the following mission objectives: #1- Find the target web server, #2- Exploit a vulnerability, #3- Gain administrative access, #4- Gather credentials, #5- Identify and access internal system, #6- Retrieve bank account data .

Completed Qualification Round Mission 5E (Team)-Operation Wounded Bear (Defensive: Protect Financial Institution), with the following mission objectives: #1- Use IDS/IPS to alert/ block initial malware infection vectors, #2- Alert/ prevent download of malicious executables, #3- Create alert for infections, #4- Remove malware from initially infected machine, #5- Find and remove other instances of malware, #6- Prevent further infections.

Completed Round 1 Challenge Mission 10E (Team)-Operation Crimson Wolf (Defensive: Ransomware), with the following mission objectives: #1- Verify networking monitoring tools are functioning, #2- Examine current email policies for risk, #3- Examine domain group/user policies for risk, #4- Verify Ransomware download.

Completed Final Round Mission 9E (Team)-Operation Mongoose (Manipulate Industrial Control System), with the following mission objectives: #1- Connect to the payload beaconing inside the payload network, #2- Find and open the documentation related to the PLC, #3- Identify the Modbus systems on the network, #4- Make a connection to the open Modbus port on the PLC system on the inside of the network, #5- Change the state of the valve parameter.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - S0056 - Skill in using network management tools to analyze network traffic patterns (e.g., simple network management protocol).
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - S0067 - Skill in identifying, modifying, and manipulating applicable system components within Windows, Unix, or Linux (e.g., passwords, user accounts, files).
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - S0266 - Skill in relevant programming languages (e.g. C++, Python, etc.).
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0001 -  Knowledge of computer networking concepts and protocols, and network security methodologies.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0010 - Knowledge of communication methods, principles, and concepts that support the network infrastructure.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0013 - Knowledge of cyber defense and vulnerability assessment tools and their capabilities.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0042 - Knowledge of incident response and handling methodologies.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0060 - Knowledge of operating systems.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0112 - Knowledge of defense-in-depth principles and network security architecture.
NICE Cybersecurity Framework - K0199 - Knowledge of security architecture concepts and enterprise architecture reference models (e.g., Zachman, Federal Enterprise Architecture [FEA]).

badge_template_activities.title: Registration in the NorCalCyber 2021 California Mayors Cyber Cup via the Cyber Skyline game platform and participation in the full 3-hour competition.
Acquire skills through the Cyber Skyline game platform practice gymnasium and competition.
Achieve the third highest score in division.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework A0005: Ability to decrypt digital data collections.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework A0066: Ability to accurately and completely source all data used in intelligence, assessment and/or planning products.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0001: Knowledge of computer networking concepts and protocols, and network security methodologies.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0005: Knowledge of cyber threats and vulnerabilities.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0009: Knowledge of application vulnerabilities.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0013: Knowledge of cyber defense and vulnerability assessment tools and their capabilities.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0018: Knowledge of encryption algorithms.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0019: Knowledge of cryptography and cryptographic key management concepts.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0024: Knowledge of database systems.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0040: Knowledge of vulnerability information dissemination sources (e.g., alerts, advisories, errata, and bulletins).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0042: Knowledge of incident response and handling methodologies.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0052: Knowledge of mathematics (e.g. logarithms, trigonometry, linear algebra, calculus, statistics, and operational analysis).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0056: Knowledge of network access, identity, and access management (e.g., public key infrastructure, Oauth, OpenID, SAML, SPML).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0058: Knowledge of network traffic analysis methods.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0119: Knowledge of hacking methodologies.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0145: Knowledge of security event correlation tools.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0224: Knowledge of system administration concepts for operating systems such as but not limited to Unix/Linux, IOS, Android, and Windows operating systems.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0301: Knowledge of packet-level analysis using appropriate tools (e.g., Wireshark, tcpdump).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0308: Knowledge of cryptology.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0342: Knowledge of penetration testing principles, tools, and techniques.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0427: Knowledge of encryption algorithms and cyber capabilities/tools (e.g., SSL, PGP).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0428: Knowledge of encryption algorithms and tools for wireless local area networks (WLANs).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0480: Knowledge of malware.

NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework K0565: Knowledge of the common networking and routing protocols (e.g. TCP/IP), services (e.g., web, mail, DNS), and how they interact to provide network communications.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0057: Skill in using protocol analyzers.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0087: Skill in deep analysis of captured malicious code (e.g., malware forensics).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0089: Skill in one-way hash functions (e.g., Secure Hash Algorithm [SHA], Message Digest Algorithm [MD5]).
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0092: Skill in identifying obfuscation techniques.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0156: Skill in performing packet-level analysis.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0221: Skill in extracting information from packet captures.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0242: Skill in interpreting vulnerability scanner results to identify vulnerabilities.

NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0270: Skill in reverse engineering (e.g., hex editing, binary packaging utilities, debugging, and strings analysis) to identify function and ownership of remote tools.
NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework S0298: Skill in verifying the integrity of all files. (e.g., checksums, Exclusive OR, secure hashes, check constraints, etc.).

a3e27660-ade0-4ab6-bb30-5639cf8cbc7a.description: The earner of this badge was part of a team that won third place in the Middle School division at the NorCalCyber 2021 California Mayors Cyber Cup for Far North on April 17, 2021. This cybersecurity competition featured the Cyber Skyline platform and was a 3-hour competition. Cyber-Guild recognizes that the Earners of the award demonstrated their knowledge of the core concepts of cybersecurity in the competition offered by Cyber Skyline.
a3e27660-ade0-4ab6-bb30-5639cf8cbc7a.name: California Mayors Cyber Cup Third Place - Far North Middle School Division
